newsitem.title: USA: Zell launches hostile $400 million bid for Chateau.
newsitem.headline: Zell launches hostile $400 million bid for Chateau.

text.p: A company led by Chicago property developer Sam Zell Wednesday launched a $400 million hostile takeover bid for manufactured home park operator Chateau Properties Inc.

The bid was the latest of several for Michigan-based Chateau, a real estate investment trust that manages communities made up of manufactured homes, and analysts said Zell's chances of success were good.
Zell's Manufactured Home Communities Inc. offered $26 a share in cash for Chateau's outstanding common shares, operating units and options, or about $400 million.

The bid comes after Chateau did not respond to an earlier, similar bid by Zell that offered cash or stock. The latest bid competes with a stock offer from Sun Communities Inc. worth about $372 million.
Chateau's stock closed Wednesday at $26.375 a share, up 25 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange. Manufactured Home's shares closed at $18.50, down 12.5 cents, also on the NYSE.
Analysts who specialise in real estate investment trusts said Zell had a good chance of success.
"I think he probably has a pretty good shot at it," said William Acheson, an analyst for Smith Barney. "It's difficult for a board to nix an all-cash deal that is very attractive."

"They've (Manufactured Home) said all along that if the board sends signals that it's not going to be accommodating, they would take it straight to shareholders," said BT Securities analyst Kevin Comer.

Chateau officials were not immediately available for comment. In the past Chateau has said that its articles of incorporation prohibit any entity or person from owning more than 7 percent of its outstanding common shares without board approval.

Analysts, however, said the 7 percent rule was designed to assure the company maintains its tax-preferred status as a real estate investment trust (REIT). To maintain such status, the five largest investors cannot own a total of more than 50 percent of the company, they said.
"The intention is to keep the tax-preferred REIT status, and it is not intended to be a defence mechanism whatsoever," said one analyst who declined to be identified.

Chateau's board members are mainly holders of operating partnership units. Although Manufactured Home's offer includes those board members, capital gains tax would keep the $26 cash offer from being attractive, analysts said. Manufactured Home's earlier stock offer was valued at about $21 a share.
"I think the board's hiding behind the 7 percent (rule) would subject them to some legal ramifications," the analyst said. "I think it's a good deal."
The tug-of-war in the industry began in July when Chateau and Colorado-based ROC Communities Inc. agreed to merge into one company, Chateau Communities.
Manufactured Home, based in Chicago, followed with an offer of $26 a share in cash, or 1.15 Manufactured Home shares per Chateau share, worth about $21 a share.
Just days later Sun Communities Inc. offered 0.892 share per Chateau share, currently valued at about $25 a share, or about $372 million.
Manufactured Home said it believes its offer provides a "substantially greater" value to Chateau's shareholders than the proposed ROC transaction or Sun Communities' bid.

The four companies operate sites for pre-fabricated homes. Most of the high-quality properties have already been taken up, and it is difficult to secure zoning for manufactured housing, analysts said.
"There are so few large portfolios left out there," Smith Barney's Acheson said.
Manufactured Home said it has received overwhelming support from Chateau shareholders, but it is still hoping for a friendly deal.
"We'd still like to work out a deal," Manufactured Home Chief Executive David Helfand said in an interview. "We're committed to this because it makes sense."
